p: Thanks fo the information. No hubbud at all - letters just make it seem so. Had we merely talked about it, there would not have been so much seeming circumstantiality.

I had hoped to be able to bring a whole system of conventional fastening for the legs; but I'm afraid thsi wouldn't fit your plan; so I'll bring the legs nicely tapered and smoothed. The fastening can be done with glued blocks, I think. Yes, walnut is darling stuff. I have the feel of it too, but I'm all for work in very had materials now. I mean crystls, of course.

We've done very well so far with the books. I've received $200, and another check for $100 is due now. I have not yet even offerec the very considerable collection of rare Western items, from which I expected most of

the sway. Am just now ready to offer them to a Chicago firm I know. The N.Y. outfit doesn't deal in Western Americana. So we should do very well before I'm through selling. And after the Western stuff, there's quite a bunch of other things.

There's something silly about the rare book game. For instance, one of my Frost items was valuable because of a printer's error. Antoher book is valuable because in the dedication to Edith Carew Roosevelt, the middle name is spelled "Karow". Piffle!
"I got sumpin you ain't got!" That's what makes rare volumes sell.
Fine findings & beautiful editions should bring a freemium. I'm all for that.
